qas.question: What is extensive pretrial discovery a part of?
What is an opt-out class action?

answers.text: the burden falls on class members to notify the court that they do not wish to be bound by the judgment

qas.question: What is an opt-in class action?

answers.text: class members must join into the class
parties generally bear their own attorneys' fees

qas.question: What does not place much weight on live testimony?
What country's courts have opt-in class actions?
What is the name of the opt-out class action?
What are pretrial dispositions designed to result in?
American legislators do not provide exceptions for what rule?

context: Generally, <a0_0><b5_0>American civil procedure<b5_0/><a0_0/> has several notable features, including extensive pretrial discovery, heavy reliance on live testimony obtained at deposition or elicited in front of a jury, and aggressive <b8_0>pretrial "law and motion"<b8_0/> practice designed to result in a pretrial disposition (that is, <a1_0>summary judgment<a1_0/>) or a settlement. <b6_0>U.S.<b6_0/> courts pioneered the concept of the opt-out class action, by which <a2_0>the burden falls on class members to notify the court that they do not wish to be bound by the judgment<a2_0/>, as opposed to opt-in class actions, where <a3_0>class members must join into the class<a3_0/>. Another unique feature is the so-called <b7_0><b9_0>American Rule<b9_0/><b7_0/> under which <a4_0>parties generally bear their own attorneys' fees<a4_0/> (as opposed to the English Rule of "loser pays"), though American legislators and courts have carved out numerous exceptions.
